objectives: Identify common basic English words and their advanced equivalents
Understand how to use advanced words in context
Improve vocabulary to sound more fluent and descriptive
Make writing and speaking more impactful and precise

sections.text: Using advanced vocabulary can make your English sound more mature, precise, and impressive. While basic words are great for everyday communication, learning advanced words helps you express your ideas more clearly and effectively. This lesson will compare common basic words with their advanced alternatives and show you how to use them in sentences.

examples.label: Ask -> Inquire
examples.value: I would like to inquire about the timings for the next bus to the city.

examples.label: Tell -> Inform
examples.value: Please inform all the villagers about the meeting tomorrow.

examples.label: Get -> Obtain / Acquire
examples.value: He worked hard to acquire the skills needed for the job.

examples.label: Use -> Utilize
examples.value: We should utilize the rainwater for our crops during the dry season.

examples.label: Start -> Commence
examples.value: The annual village festival will commence next Monday.

examples.label: End -> Conclude
examples.value: The village head will conclude the meeting with a final announcement.

examples.label: Help -> Assist
examples.value: The government has sent a team to assist the farmers with the new equipment.

examples.label: Good -> Excellent / Superb
examples.value: The quality of this year's harvest is excellent.

examples.label: Bad -> Awful / Terrible
examples.value: The condition of the road after the heavy rain was terrible.

examples.label: Happy -> Delighted / Ecstatic
examples.value: She was delighted to hear that her son had passed the exam.

examples.label: Sad -> Sorrowful / Melancholy
examples.value: He was sorrowful after hearing the news of his old friend's illness.

examples.label: Big -> Enormous / Gigantic
examples.value: An enormous banyan tree stands in the center of the village.

examples.label: Small -> Tiny / Minuscule
examples.value: The details in the painting were so minuscule they were hard to see.

examples.label: Important -> Crucial / Essential
examples.value: Water is essential for the survival of all living things.

examples.label: Interesting -> Fascinating / Captivating
examples.value: My grandfather told us a fascinating story about the old temple.

examples.label: Scared -> Terrified / Petrified
examples.value: The little boy was terrified of the loud thunder during the storm.

examples.label: Tired -> Exhausted / Fatigued
examples.value: After working in the fields all day, the farmer was completely exhausted.

examples.label: Smart -> Intelligent / Brilliant
examples.value: She came up with a brilliant idea to solve the water problem.

examples.label: Brave -> Courageous / Valiant
examples.value: The courageous soldier saved the entire village from the flood.

examples.label: Think -> Ponder / Contemplate
examples.value: He sat by the river to contemplate his future plans.

examples.label: Show -> Demonstrate / Illustrate
examples.value: The officer will demonstrate how to use the new farming tool.

examples.label: Rich -> Wealthy / Affluent
examples.value: The affluent landlord owned most of the land in the area.

examples.label: Poor -> Impoverished / Destitute
examples.value: The long drought left many farming families impoverished.

examples.label: Old -> Ancient / Elderly
examples.value: The elderly woman shared stories of the ancient traditions of her village.

examples.label: Angry -> Furious / Enraged
examples.value: He was furious when he found out that someone had damaged his crops.

examples.label: Beautiful -> Exquisite / Stunning
examples.value: The bride wore an exquisite saree on her wedding day.

examples.label: Fast -> Swift / Rapid
examples.value: The river's current became swift after the heavy rainfall.

examples.label: Slow -> Leisurely / Sluggish
examples.value: The bullock cart made its way down the road at a leisurely pace.

examples.label: Sure -> Certain
examples.value: I am certain that it will rain this evening.

examples.label: Clear -> Transparent / Apparent
examples.value: His reason for being late was apparent to everyone.

examples.label: Wrong -> Erroneous
examples.value: The initial calculations in the report were erroneous.

examples.label: Empty -> Vacant
examples.value: The old house at the end of the street has been vacant for years.

sections.text: Here are some tips to help you start using more advanced words:
usage_examples: Tip 1: Don't try to learn all the words at once. Start with 5-10 words, understand their meaning, and practice using them in your own sentences.
Tip 2: Use a dictionary to check the exact meaning and usage of a new word. Pay attention to the example sentences.
Tip 3: Try to use one or two new words in your daily conversations or writing. This will help you remember them.
Tip 4: Read more books and articles. When you see a new word, look it up and try to understand how it's used in the sentence.
Tip 5: Context is key. Make sure the advanced word fits the situation. Sometimes a simple word is the best choice.

We had terrible weather during our trip.
I was delighted to receive your letter.
They live in an enormous house with ten rooms.
